documents.summary: This circular extends the timeline for implementing the SEBI circular regarding margin obligations to be given by way of pledge/re-pledge in the Depository System. The original effective date of September 01, 2025, has been extended to October 10, 2025, due to requests from depositories for more time to complete system developments and testing.

documents.summary: This circular allows Investment Advisers (IAs) and Research Analysts (RAs) to use liquid mutual funds and overnight mutual funds, as an alternative to bank deposits, for meeting deposit requirements as specified under SEBI (Investment Advisers) Regulations, 2013 and SEBI (Research Analysts) Regulations, 2014. The circular directs IAASB/RAASB (BSE Limited) to put in place necessary systems and procedures for implementation and requires IAs and RAs to comply with the deposit requirements by September 30, 2025.

key_clauses.clause_title: Deposit Requirement for Investment Advisers and Research Analysts
key_clauses.clause_content: Investment Advisers (IAs) and Research Analysts (RAs) are required to maintain a deposit as specified by SEBI from time to time, previously required to be maintained with a scheduled bank marked as lien in favor of the respective IAASB or RAASB.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates a deposit requirement for IAs and RAs, ensuring they have sufficient financial resources and are committed to their responsibilities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this document, but non-compliance with deposit requirements may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: IAs and RAs can now maintain the deposit in the form of units of liquid mutual fund or an overnight mutual fund or as a deposit maintained with a scheduled bank. Such deposit shall be marked as lien in favor of IAASB or RAASB, as the case may be.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause provides flexibility to IAs and RAs by allowing them to use liquid assets like mutual funds for meeting the deposit requirement, potentially improving their liquidity management.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this document, but failure to maintain the required deposit may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: IAs and RAs shall comply with the deposit requirements latest by September 30, 2025.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause sets a specific deadline for IAs and RAs to adjust their deposit arrangements to comply with the new regulations.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this document, but failure to comply by the deadline may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: IAASB/RAASB (BSE Limited) is directed to put in place necessary systems and procedures for implementation of the provisions of this circular and bring the same to the notice of IAs/RAs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause places the responsibility on IAASB/RAASB to facilitate the implementation of the new regulations and ensure that IAs and RAs are informed about the changes.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this document, but failure to implement the necessary systems and procedures may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

documents.summary: This circular reviews the framework for conversion of Private Listed InvIT into Public InvIT as outlined in Chapter 14 of the Master Circular for Infrastructure Investment Trusts (InvITs) dated May 15, 2024. It streamlines requirements for minimum unitholding by sponsors and sponsor groups and aligns the procedure and disclosure requirements for public offers with those of follow-on offers.

key_clauses.clause_title: Minimum Unitholding Requirement for Sponsors and Sponsor Groups
key_clauses.clause_content: The sponsor(s) and sponsor group(s) shall comply with the minimum unitholding requirement specified in Regulation 12(3) and 12(3A) of the InvIT Regulations, as applicable, at all times.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that sponsors and sponsor groups maintain a minimum level of investment in the InvIT, aligning their interests with those of other unitholders.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Lock-in Period for Sponsor and Sponsor Group Units
key_clauses.clause_content: The lock-in on units held by the sponsor(s) and sponsor group(s) to comply with the minimum unitholding requirement mentioned in paragraph 14.6.1 above shall be as specified in Regulation 12(5) of the InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Violation of lock-in provisions would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Alignment of Public Offer Procedure with Follow-on Offer
key_clauses.clause_content: The procedure and disclosure requirements for public offer of units to convert a private listed InvIT into a public InvIT are aligned with the procedure and disclosure requirements applicable for follow-on offer.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Simplifies the process for conversion by leveraging existing regulations for follow-on offers, reducing compliance burden.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to comply with follow-on offer requirements would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: For such public issue, the InvIT shall comply with the requirements for follow-on offer prescribed under InvIT Regulations and the circulars issued thereunder including any amendments thereto.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: InvITs must adhere to all rules and guidelines applicable to follow-on offers when converting from private to public.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance with follow-on offer requirements will result in regulatory penalties.

key_clauses.clause_content: The disclosure requirements applicable for follow-on offer under InvIT Regulations shall be followed.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that investors receive adequate information about the InvIT and the public issue.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Inadequate or misleading disclosures would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

documents.summary: This circular introduces a policy for joint annual inspections by Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs) to ease the burden on intermediaries and improve supervision effectiveness. It outlines a framework for joint inspections, information sharing, and revised criteria for selecting entities for annual inspection, aiming for optimum resource utilization and a comprehensive view of entity operations.

key_clauses.clause_content: Entities selected for annual inspections will be inspected jointly by all exchanges along with their depository participant (DP) operations (if broker is also registered as DP) and clearing activity (if the broker is undertaking clearing for other brokers). DP operations and clearing activity undertaken by entities shall be inspected by Depositories and Clearing Corporations, respectively.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Reduces the frequency of inspections for brokers/DPs, minimizing disruption to their operations and optimizing resource utilization for both MIIs and intermediaries.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs shall establish an information sharing mechanism with one another for sharing of inspection observations of entities who hold multiple registrations with MIIs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances the effectiveness of supervision by providing MIIs with a more comprehensive view of entities' operations across different segments and registrations.

key_clauses.clause_content:
The criteria for annual inspection are revised as follows:
a. Top 25 entities paying high and recurring penalties for non-reporting or short reporting of margin/Client Code modification/CTCL mismatch fines or any other similar high risk compliance issue.
b. Top 25 entities in terms of investor complaints and arbitration cases filed by investors, as percentage of number of active clients.
c. Top 25 entities based on ‘High risk score’ under Risk Based Supervision.
Entities that do not fall under any of the above categories shall be inspected by the MIIs at least once in three years.
Entities inspected in preceding two years by any of the MII’s/SEBI and/or entities that have not executed a single trade during last two financial years may not be considered for inspection under the above criteria.
Inspections of Professional Clearing Members shall be conducted jointly by Clearing Corporations once in two years.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Focuses inspection efforts on entities posing higher risks, such as those with frequent penalties, high investor complaints, or high-risk scores. It also sets a minimum inspection frequency for other entities.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs have the prerogative to carry out special purpose/limited inspections based on any triggers like patterns found during investor complaint resolution/Arbitration, complaints on specific malpractices of a broker or references from various authorities. The inspection shall be irrespective of the fact of when the last inspection was carried out.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Allows MIIs to address specific concerns or investigate potential malpractices promptly, regardless of the regular inspection schedule.

key_clauses.clause_title: Rescission and Amendment of Previous Circulars
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI Circular CIR/HO/MIRSD/MIRSD2/CIR/P/2017/73 dated June 30, 2017 stands rescinded and para 14 of Master Circular for Stock Brokers dated June 17, 2025 stands amended as per this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Updates the regulatory framework by replacing the previous circular and amending the master circular to align with the new policy for joint annual inspections.

documents.summary: This circular modifies the handling of review, appeal, or waiver requests of penalties arising from actions taken by the Member Committee (MC) of Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs). It mandates that requests against Internal Committee (IC) actions or actions per pre-approved policy are placed before the MC, while requests against MC actions are handled by a mechanism set up by the Governing Board with Public Interest Directors and/or Independent External Professionals.

key_clauses.clause_title: Terms of Reference of Statutory Committees
key_clauses.clause_content: The Terms of Reference (ToR) of Statutory Committees of Stock Exchanges, Clearing Corporations and Depositories (collectively referred as Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs)) have been prescribed under Paragraph 2.2.2 of Chapter 6 of SEBI Master Circular No. SEBI/HO/MRD-PoD2/CIR/P/2024/00181 dated December 30, 2024 for “Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations” and under Paragraph 4.66(B) of Section-4 of SEBI Master Circular No. SEBI/HO/MRD/MRD-PoD-1/P/CIR/2024/168 dated December 03, 2024 for “Depositories”.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause establishes the foundation for the regulatory framework governing the statutory committees of MIIs, ensuring they operate within defined parameters.

key_clauses.clause_title: Review, Appeal or Waiver of Penalty
key_clauses.clause_content: Any review, appeal or waiver of penalty filed shall be placed before MC for its consideration.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause outlines the initial process for handling requests for review, appeal, or waiver of penalties, ensuring that the MC considers such requests.

key_clauses.clause_title: Handling of Requests for Review, Appeal or Waiver of Penalty
key_clauses.clause_content: Any request for review, appeal or waiver of penalty filed against actions taken by the Internal Committee (IC) of the Member Committee (MC), or against actions taken by the MII as per pre-approved policy on regulatory action shall be placed before the MC for its consideration.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause specifies that requests against IC actions or actions based on pre-approved policies are to be considered by the MC.

key_clauses.clause_title: Mechanism for Handling Requests Against MC Actions
key_clauses.clause_content: Any request for review, appeal or waiver of penalty filed against actions taken by the MC from the date of implementation of this circular shall be handled by a mechanism setup by the Governing Board of the MII with Public Interest Directors and/or Independent External Professionals not forming part of the MC. The Governing Board shall issue the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) with regard to handling of such review, appeal or waiver of penalty requests, if any, emanating out of actions taken by the MC.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates a separate mechanism, independent of the MC, to handle requests against MC actions, ensuring impartiality and fairness. It also requires the Governing Board to establish an SOP.

key_clauses.clause_content: For further appeal against the decisions emanating out of the appeal mechanism of the MII, the members or participants would be free to approach appropriate authority based on the applicable laws.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause clarifies that members or participants can appeal decisions from the MII's appeal mechanism to appropriate authorities as per applicable laws.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular mandates compliance with the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 by all regulated entities (REs). It requires REs to ensure digital accessibility of their platforms for persons with disabilities, including conducting accessibility audits, implementing necessary changes, and reporting compliance annually.

key_clauses.clause_content: All Regulated Entities (REs) must ensure their Digital Platforms are compliant with the provisions of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 (RPwD Act, 2016) and corresponding rules, specifically Section 40 (Accessibility), Section 42 (Access to information and communication technology), Section 46 (Time limit for accessibility by service providers), and Rule 15(1)(c) of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Rules, 2017 (Rules for Accessibility).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must modify their digital platforms to ensure accessibility for persons with disabilities, potentially requiring significant investment in technology and training.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular (31.07.2025)
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance with the RPwD Act, 2016 may attract penalties under that Act.

key_clauses.clause_content: REs shall ensure that their Digital Platforms and content published on the digital platform strictly adhere to the accessibility standards and guidelines, including: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 or latest version; Accessibility guidelines as described in the latest version of Guidelines for Indian Government Websites (GIGW); IS 17802: Indian Standards on Accessibility Requirements for Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Products and Services; and Provisions of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 and corresponding rules for digital accessibility mentioned in this Circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must adhere to specific technical standards for digital accessibility, requiring expertise in WCAG, GIGW, and IS 17802.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular (31.07.2025)
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance with the RPwD Act, 2016 may attract penalties under that Act.

key_clauses.clause_content: The compliance with this circular shall be reviewed and approved by Managing Director or the Managing Partner or the Proprietor of the REs, as may be applicable. REs shall designate any senior officer as the Nodal Officer for digital accessibility compliance. In the absence of an officially designated Nodal Officer, the Compliance Officer or the Proprietor shall be deemed to be the Nodal Officer for ensuring digital accessibility compliance.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must establish internal governance structures to oversee and ensure compliance with the digital accessibility requirements.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular (31.07.2025)

key_clauses.clause_content: A grievance redressal mechanism specific to accessibility issues shall be institutionalized within the REs. Channels such as email, helpline, and web forms must be user-friendly for PwDs. The system must include provisions for escalation to senior officers.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must establish and maintain a dedicated grievance redressal system for accessibility-related complaints.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular (31.07.2025)

key_clauses.clause_content: The Digital Platforms of the REs shall include features such as Indian Sign Language (ISL) videos, closed captioning, descriptive audio, and alternate text for images. key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must implement specific accessibility features on their digital platforms and ensure documents are accessible.

key_clauses.clause_content: Training modules that give detailed understanding on digital accessibility (website, mobile application, etc.) shall be part of all internal training programs for staff and third-party service providers who are developing and publishing content for dissemination via Digital Platforms. The trainings should cover behavioural training, assistive tools, and inclusive experience for normal as well as differently abled users.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must train their staff and service providers on digital accessibility best practices.

key_clauses.clause_content: All REs shall ensure that digital KYC, e-KYC, and video KYC processes include alternatives to accommodate differently abled users/clients. Any application of a client with disability shall be rejected by the REs only after a review by a designated human officer and the said officer shall be empowered to override automated rejections and approve applications on a case by case basis, thereby ensuring equitable access to services of the REs for persons with disabilities.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must adapt their KYC and registration processes to accommodate persons with disabilities, including manual review of rejected applications.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular (31.07.2025)

key_clauses.clause_content: All REs shall initiate a comprehensive accessibility audit of their digital platforms including websites, mobile apps, portals through International Association of Accessibility Professionals (“IAAP”). The audit shall follow the latest WCAG, GIGW guidelines and RPwD Act and rules made thereunder and also SEBI from time to time. The said accessibility audit shall include usability testing by persons with disabilities. Based on the audit findings, REs shall prepare and implement a plan for remediation of audit observations. Existing digital platforms must be upgraded to meet accessibility standards within the transition timeline. All REs shall conduct annual accessibility audits of their digital platforms including websites, mobile apps, portals through IAAP certified accessibility professionals and reports shall be submitted as per the mechanism specified in direction 1.4 in Section 1 of this Annexure.

The responsibility to ensure the accessibility of a Digital Platform shall lie with the REs. Accessibility requirements shall be part of all Request for Proposals (“RFPs”) and procurement contracts of the REs and evaluation criteria of the REs shall assign due weightage to accessibility readiness.

It removes the mandatory requirement for NRIs to notify Clearing Members and obtain a Custodial Participant (CP) Code, streamlining the monitoring of NRI position limits, which will now be managed similarly to client-level position limits.

documents.summary: This circular clarifies the mechanism for monitoring compliance with the Minimum Investment Threshold for Specialized Investment Funds (SIFs). It outlines the actions to be taken in case of a breach, including freezing units, providing a notice period for rebalancing, and automatic redemption if the threshold is not met within the specified timeframe.

key_clauses.clause_content: The Asset Management Company shall monitor compliance with the Minimum Investment Threshold on a daily basis and ensure that there are no active breaches. The AMC shall ensure that the investor’s total investment value does not fall below the Minimum Investment Threshold due to redemption transactions initiated by the investor.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs must implement systems to monitor investor holdings in SIFs daily to ensure compliance with the minimum investment threshold.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_title: Action in case of Active Breach
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of any active breach of the Minimum Investment Threshold by an investor, including through transactions on stock exchanges or off-market transfers: all units of such investor held across investment strategies of the concerned SIF shall be frozen for debit, and a notice of 30 calendar days shall be given to such investor to rebalance the investments in order to comply with the Minimum Investment Threshold.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs must freeze units and issue a notice to investors who breach the minimum investment threshold.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: In case investor rebalances his/her investments in SIF within the notice period of 30 calendar days, the units of SIF of such investor shall be unfreezed, and no further action shall be taken with regard to compliance with Minimum Investment Threshold.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: If the investor rectifies the breach within 30 days, the AMC must unfreeze the units.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_title: Automatic Redemption upon Failure to Rebalance
key_clauses.clause_content: In case the investor fails to rebalance the investments within the aforesaid 30 calendar day period, the frozen units shall be automatically redeemed by the AMC, at the applicable Net Asset Value of the next immediate business day after the 30th calendar day of the notice period.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs are required to automatically redeem the units of investors who fail to rebalance their investments within the 30-day notice period.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: For the purpose of SIF, the ‘Active Breach’ shall mean fall in the aggregate value of an investor’s total investment across all investment strategies of SIF, below the Minimum Investment Threshold of INR 10 lakh, on account of any transactions (i.e. redemption, transfer, sale etc.) initiated by the investor.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines what constitutes an 'Active Breach' for the purpose of this circular.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Consent by signature on the terms and conditions including most important terms and conditions (MITC) shall not be mandatory for the clients who are institutional investors or qualified institutional buyers. However, RAs/research entities are required to disclose the terms and conditions of research services including MITC to these clients.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Eases the compliance burden for RAs by removing the mandatory consent requirement for institutional investors and QIBs, while still requiring disclosure of terms and conditions.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this clause, but failure to disclose terms and conditions would likely result in regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: RA Regulations cover all securities as defined under clause (h) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that RA regulations are not limited to equity and equity-linked securities but extend to all securities as defined in the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956.

key_clauses.clause_title: Obligations of Investment Advisers, Credit Rating Agencies, Asset Management Companies and Fund Managers
key_clauses.clause_content: Investment Advisers, Credit Rating Agencies, Asset Management Companies and Fund Managers are not required to be registered under RA Regulations. However, in case such intermediaries issue/circulate/distribute research reports to public or general investors and/or if they or their directors or employees make public appearance, they shall be required to comply with Chapter III of the RA Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the obligations of these intermediaries when they engage in activities that fall under the purview of RA regulations, even if they are not primarily registered as RAs.

key_clauses.clause_content: Proxy Advisers are required to obtain registration from SEBI under RA Regulations. All the provisions of Chapter II, III, IV, V and VI of RA Regulations shall apply mutatis mutandis to the proxy adviser. The proxy adviser shall be required to additionally disclose the extent of research involved in a particular recommendation and the extent and/or effectiveness of its controls and procedures in ensuring the accuracy of issuer data; policies and procedures for interacting with issuers, informing issuers about the recommendation and review of recommendations. Proxy adviser is required to maintain the record of his voting recommendations and furnish the same to SEBI on request.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies the registration and disclosure requirements for proxy advisors, ensuring transparency and accountability in their recommendations.

key_clauses.clause_content: Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not deal or trade any securities that the research analyst recommends or follows within 30 days before and 5 days after the publication of a research report on the subject company. Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not deal or trade directly or indirectly in securities that he reviews in a manner contrary to his given recommendation. Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not purchase or receive securities of the issuer before the issuer's initial public offering, if the issuer is principally engaged in the same types of business as companies that the research analyst follows or recommends.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Imposes restrictions on trading activities to prevent conflicts of interest and ensure the integrity of research recommendations.

key_clauses.clause_content: A non-individual research analyst or research entity is required to appoint a compliance officer who shall be responsible for monitoring the compliance in respect of the requirements of the Act, RA regulations and circulars issued by SEBI. A non-individual research analyst may appoint an independent professional who is a member of ICAI or ICSI or ICMAI or member of any other professional body as may be specified by the SEBI, provided such a professional holds a relevant certification from NISM, as may be specified by the SEBI.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates the appointment of a compliance officer to oversee compliance with RA regulations, ensuring accountability and adherence to regulatory requirements.

key_clauses.clause_content: RA/research entity can provide distribution services on products/securities provided they are not providing research services on such products/securities being distributed and are providing such distribution services through separately identifiable department or division or business unit within the same entity or through a separate entity on an arms’ length basis.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the conditions under which RAs can provide both research and distribution services, ensuring segregation of activities to mitigate conflicts of interest.

key_clauses.clause_content: Persons associated with research services shall obtain the relevant certification from NISM as specified by SEBI within one year from the date of this circular or within the timeline as may be specified by SEBI.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that client and public facing persons are deemed to be persons associated with research services and must obtain NISM certification.
key_clauses.effective_date: July 23, 2026 (one year from the date of the circular)

key_clauses.clause_title: Exemption from Client Level Segregation for Institutional Clients/QIBs
key_clauses.clause_content: Even in cases where research service is not exclusively provided to institutional clients/QIBs, all research analysts/entities are exempted from ‘client level segregation of research and distribution activities’ for their institutional clients/QIBs if such a client provides a standard waiver. Client may also provide such standard waiver through e-mail or any other electronically verifiable mode. However, such exemption shall not be applicable in case of clients other than institutional clients/QIBs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides an exemption from client-level segregation requirements for institutional clients/QIBs who provide a standard waiver, reducing compliance burden for RAs.

documents.summary: This circular announces a special window for re-lodgement of transfer requests for physical shares that were lodged before April 1, 2019, and rejected due to deficiencies. The window will be open for six months, from July 07, 2025, to January 06, 2026, and all re-lodged shares will be issued in demat mode.

key_clauses.clause_content: Transfer of securities in physical mode was discontinued with effect from April 01, 2019. Subsequently, it was clarified that transfer deeds lodged prior to deadline of April 01, 2019 and rejected/returned due to deficiency in the documents may be re-lodged with requisite documents. It was further decided to fix March 31, 2021 as the cut-off date for re-lodgement of transfer deeds.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause establishes the initial discontinuation of physical share transfers and the original deadline for re-lodgement of deficient documents.

key_clauses.clause_title: Special Window for Re-lodgement of Transfer Requests
key_clauses.clause_content: In order to facilitate ease of investing for investors and to secure the rights of investors in the securities which were purchased by them, it has been decided to open a special window only for re-lodgement of transfer deeds, which were lodged prior to the deadline of April 01, 2019 and rejected/returned/not attended to due to deficiency in the documents/process/or otherwise, for a period of six months from July 07, 2025 till January 06, 2026.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause allows investors who missed the original deadline to re-lodge their transfer requests, providing them with another opportunity to transfer their shares.

key_clauses.clause_content: During this period, the securities that are re-lodged for transfer (including those requests that are pending with the listed company / RTA, as on date) shall be issued only in demat mode. Due process shall be followed for such transfer-cum-demat requests.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates that all securities re-lodged during the special window must be issued in dematerialized (demat) form, ensuring compliance with current regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: Listed companies, RTAs and Stock Exchanges shall publicize the opening of this special window through various media including print and social media, on a bi-monthly basis during the six-month period.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause requires listed companies, RTAs, and Stock Exchanges to actively inform investors about the special window, ensuring maximum participation.

key_clauses.clause_content: RTAs/listed companies shall have focussed teams to attend to such requests.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates RTAs and listed companies to allocate dedicated resources to handle the re-lodgement requests efficiently.

key_clauses.clause_content: RTAs/listed companies shall provide reports on: 7.1 publicity; and 7.2 shares re-lodged for transfer cum demat in the format specified by SEBI (provided at Annexure-A) on monthly basis.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause imposes a reporting obligation on RTAs and listed companies to provide SEBI with information on publicity efforts and the number of shares re-lodged for transfer-cum-demat.

key_clauses.clause_content: This circular is being issued in exercise of powers conferred under Section 11 (1) of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992, read with regulation 102 of the SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015 and SEBI (Registrars to an Issue and Share Transfer Agents) Regulations, 1993 to protect the interests of investors in securities and to promote the development of, and to regulate the securities market.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause clarifies the legal basis for the issuance of the circular.

documents.summary: This circular revises the frequency of Product Advisory Committee (PAC) meetings as mandated in the 'Master Circular for Commodity Derivatives Segment'. Specifically, it modifies the meeting frequency requirement for agricultural commodities, reducing it to at least once a year, while maintaining the requirement of at least twice a year for other commodities or more frequently as needed.

key_clauses.clause_content: Paragraph 2.4.4.i. of the ‘Master Circular for Commodity Derivatives Segment’ dated August 04, 2023, is revised to state that the PAC shall meet at least twice a year and more frequently as and when required. However, in the case of agricultural commodities, the PAC shall meet at least once a year.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Stock exchanges with commodity derivatives segments, particularly those dealing with agricultural commodities, are impacted. They need to adjust their PAC meeting schedules to comply with the revised frequency.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance with the Master Circular may attract penalties as per SEBI regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: The Circular shall come into force with immediate effect.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Stock exchanges must immediately implement the changes outlined in the circular.

key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Stock exchanges are responsible for informing their members about the changes and making the circular publicly available.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular mandates the adoption of standardized, validated, and exclusive UPI IDs for payment collection by SEBI-registered investor-facing intermediaries to enhance accessibility and safety in the securities market. It outlines the structure of the dedicated UPI address, the framework for allocation and use of @valid UPI handles, transaction limits, and responsibilities of intermediaries, self-certified syndicate banks, MIIs, and RTAs.

key_clauses.clause_title: Mandatory Adoption of Structured UPI Mechanism
key_clauses.clause_content: It is mandatory for intermediaries to obtain and make available the structured UPI address to their investors, although the use of this mechanism by investors shall remain optional. Intermediaries are advised and encouraged to actively promote and facilitate the adoption of this mechanism among their investors.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must implement the structured UPI mechanism and educate investors about its use. This will require changes to payment systems and investor communication strategies.

key_clauses.clause_content: The UPI address will consist of a username (alphanumeric ID generated for the user followed by an abbreviation representing their intermediary segment) and a unique handle linked to the bank of the registered intermediaries (@valid combined with the name of the self-certified syndicate banks).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must adhere to the specified structure when generating UPI IDs. This ensures uniformity and verifiability of payment addresses.

key_clauses.clause_content: UPI IDs with the handle @valid shall be exclusively designated for payment collection by intermediaries registered with SEBI under merchant category code 6211. The usage of these UPI handles for any activity other than the intended payment collection shall not be permitted.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries are restricted to using the @valid UPI handles solely for payment collection purposes. Misuse of these handles is prohibited.

key_clauses.clause_content: The upper limit of up to ₹5 lakhs per day for capital market transactions (done through UPI) shall be available, subject to periodic review and further evaluation as necessary.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Capital market transactions through UPI are capped at ₹5 lakhs per day. This limit is subject to change based on future reviews.

key_clauses.clause_title: Verification of UPI IDs and Bank Account Details
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI is developing a functionality named “SEBI Check” to allow investors to verify the authenticity of UPI IDs either by scanning a QR code or by entering the UPI ID manually. This tool will also include a feature to confirm the bank details such as bank account number and Indian Financial System Code (IFSC) of an intermediary.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Investors will have a tool to verify the legitimacy of intermediaries' UPI IDs and bank details, enhancing security and reducing the risk of fraud.

key_clauses.clause_content: Intermediaries must ensure their mobile number and email address are updated in the SI Portal, obtain new UPI IDs from banks, continue existing SIPs with old handles while new/renewed SIPs must use new UPI IDs, and create investor awareness about new payment handles and “SEBI Check” functionality.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries have specific obligations related to updating information, obtaining new UPI IDs, managing existing and new SIPs, and educating investors.

key_clauses.clause_content: Self-Certified Syndicate Banks must obtain API access, issue UPI IDs only after verification using the utility, and perform proper due diligence while issuing the UPI IDs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Banks have specific obligations related to API access, verification processes, and due diligence when issuing UPI IDs to intermediaries.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs are required to make necessary changes at their end to enable intermediaries to access SI Portal through them and create investor awareness about new payment handles and “SEBI Check” functionality.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: MIIs must update their systems to facilitate intermediary access and participate in investor awareness campaigns.

key_clauses.clause_content: Intermediaries must discontinue the use of old UPI IDs by T + 180 Days (except those mentioned in Para 6.1.3 regarding ongoing Mutual Funds SIPs).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must transition to the new UPI IDs within the specified timeframe, ceasing the use of old UPI IDs.

documents.summary: This circular provides a framework for the issuance of Environment, Social, and Governance (ESG) debt securities, excluding green debt securities, such as social bonds, sustainability bonds, and sustainability-linked bonds. It outlines the definitions, disclosure requirements, responsibilities of issuers, and measures to mitigate the risk of purpose-washing, aiming to facilitate the raising of funds through these instruments while ensuring transparency and investor protection.

key_clauses.clause_content: Regulation 2(1)(oa) of the SEBI (Issue and Listing of Non-Convertible Securities) Regulations 2021 defines ESG debt securities as green debt securities, social bonds, sustainability bonds, sustainability-linked bonds, or any other type of bonds issued in accordance with international frameworks adapted to suit Indian requirements as specified by the Board.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the scope of ESG debt securities under SEBI regulations, providing a basis for regulatory oversight and compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: Regulation 12A of the SEBI NCS Regulations states that an issuer desirous of issuing and listing ESG Debt Securities shall comply with such conditions as may be specified by the Board.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Establishes the requirement for issuers to adhere to SEBI-specified conditions for issuing and listing ESG debt securities.

key_clauses.clause_content: This circular applies to ESG debt securities labelled as ‘social bonds’, ‘sustainability bonds’ and ‘sustainability-linked bonds’ which are listed or proposed to be listed on a recognized stock exchange.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines the scope of the circular's application to specific types of ESG debt securities.

key_clauses.clause_content: Debt securities shall be labelled as ‘social bonds’ or ‘sustainability bonds’ or ‘sustainability-linked bonds’ only if the funds raised are proposed to be utilised for financing or refinancing projects and/or assets aligned with recognized standards such as ICMA Principles/Guidelines, Climate Bonds Standard, ASEAN Standards, European Union Standards, or any framework specified by a financial sector regulator in India.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Sets conditions for labeling debt securities as social, sustainability, or sustainability-linked bonds, ensuring alignment with recognized standards.

key_clauses.clause_content: “Social Bonds” means a debt security issued for raising funds, subject to the conditions as may be specified by the Board from time to time, to be utilised for social project(s) that directly aim to address or mitigate a specific social issue and/or seek to achieve positive social outcomes especially but not exclusively for a target population, falling under specified categories.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines Social Bonds and specifies the categories of social projects eligible for funding through these bonds.

key_clauses.clause_content: ‘Sustainability bonds’ means a debt security issued for raising funds, subject to the conditions as may be specified by the Board from time to time, to be utilised for finance or re-finance of a combination of eligible green project(s) and social project(s) as specified under the definition of green bonds and social bonds respectively.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines Sustainability Bonds as those funding a combination of green and social projects.

key_clauses.clause_content: ‘Sustainability-linked bonds’ means a debt security which has its financial and/or structural characteristics linked to predefined sustainability objectives of the Issuer, subject to the condition that such objectives are measured through predefined Sustainability Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and assessed against predefined Sustainability Performance Targets (SPTs).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines Sustainability-linked Bonds as those with financial characteristics tied to the issuer's sustainability objectives, measured by KPIs and SPTs.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds must make initial disclosures in the offer document (as specified in Part I of Annexure-A) and provide continuous disclosures in their annual report and financial results (as specified in Part II of Annexure-A). They must also appoint an independent third-party reviewer/certifier (as specified in Part III of Annexure-A).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates specific disclosures and third-party review for social bonds to ensure transparency and accountability.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of sustainability bonds must comply with the provisions specified for green debt security as specified in chapter IX of the NCS Master Circular and for social bonds as specified in Annexure-A of this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies that sustainability bonds must adhere to the disclosure requirements for both green debt securities and social bonds.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of sustainability-linked bonds must make initial disclosures in the offer document (as specified in Part I of Annexure B) and provide continuous disclosures in their annual report and financial results (as specified in Part II of Annexure B). They must also appoint an independent third-party reviewer/certifier (as specified in Part III of Annexure B).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates specific disclosures and third-party review for sustainability-linked bonds to ensure transparency and accountability.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds/sustainability bonds must maintain a decision-making process to determine the continuing eligibility of projects and ensure that funds are used only for the stated purpose.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Places responsibility on issuers to ensure the ongoing eligibility of projects and proper use of funds.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers must continuously monitor the social/sustainable impact of operations, avoid using funds for ineligible purposes, disclose instances of non-compliance, avoid misleading labels, quantify negative externalities, and avoid false claims of third-party certification. In case of non-compliance, early redemption of debt securities may be required by majority of debenture holders.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Imposes measures to prevent 'purpose-washing' and ensure the integrity of social and sustainability bonds.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Early redemption of debt securities may be required by majority of debenture holders.

key_clauses.clause_title: Post Listing Obligations for SME Exchange
key_clauses.clause_content: An Issuer who is eligible to list specified securities on SME exchange and intends to issue ESG debt securities shall have to comply with the post listing obligations as specified under ‘Continuous disclosure requirements’ specified in Annexure-A and Annexure-B, and paragraph 2 of Chapter IX (green Debt Securities) of SEBI NCS Master Circular bi-annually.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies the post listing obligations for SME exchanges.

key_clauses.clause_content: The issuer shall appoint an independent third party reviewer/ certifier, to ascertain that the ESG labelled debt securities are in alignment with any of the recognized standards mentioned at paragraph V.3 and/ or paragraph V.4 above (including review/certification of the processes including project evaluation and selection criteria, project categories eligible for financing by social bonds, etc), in compliance with specified conditions.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates the appointment of an independent third party reviewer/certifier to ensure compliance with recognized standards.

actionable_items.action_title: Comply with Disclosure Requirements for Social Bonds
actionable_items.action_description: Issuers intending to issue social bonds must make the initial disclosures specified in Part I of Annexure-A in the offer document and provide continuous disclosures as specified in Part II of Annexure-A in their annual report and financial results.

actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Adherence to the disclosure requirements outlined in Annexure-A, including details of social objectives, decision-making process, tracking of proceeds, and impact reporting.

actionable_items.action_title: Comply with Disclosure Requirements for Sustainability Bonds
actionable_items.action_description: Issuers intending to issue sustainability bonds must comply with the provisions specified for green debt security as specified in chapter IX of the NCS Master Circular and for social bonds as specified in Annexure-A of this circular.
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: Effective from June 05, 2025, for all issuances of sustainability bonds.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Adherence to the disclosure requirements outlined in chapter IX of the NCS Master Circular and Annexure-A, including details of social objectives, decision-making process, tracking of proceeds, and impact reporting.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Offer document, annual report, financial results, and supporting documentation for disclosures.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Review by stock exchanges and SEBI.
actionable_items.non_compliance_consequences: Potential regulatory action by SEBI, including penalties or restrictions on future issuances.

actionable_items.action_title: Comply with Disclosure Requirements for Sustainability-Linked Bonds
actionable_items.action_description: Issuers intending to issue sustainability-linked bonds must make the initial disclosures specified in Part I of Annexure B in the offer document and provide continuous disclosures as specified in Part II of Annexure B in their annual report and financial results.
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: Effective from June 05, 2025, for all issuances of sustainability-linked bonds.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Adherence to the disclosure requirements outlined in Annexure-B, including details of KPIs, SPTs, and financial/structural characteristics linked to sustainability performance.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Offer document, annual report, financial results, and supporting documentation for disclosures.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Review by stock exchanges and SEBI.
actionable_items.non_compliance_consequences: Potential regulatory action by SEBI, including penalties or restrictions on future issuances.

actionable_items.action_description: Issuers of social bonds and sustainability-linked bonds must appoint an independent third-party reviewer/certifier to undertake the activities and responsibilities specified in Annexure-A (Part III) and Annexure-B (Part III), respectively.
actionable_items.responsible_parties: Issuers of social bonds and sustainability-linked bonds
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: Effective from June 05, 2025, for all issuances of social bonds and sustainability-linked bonds.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Appointment of a qualified and independent reviewer/certifier with expertise in assessing ESG debt securities. The reviewer must be independent of the issuer and remunerated in a way that prevents conflicts of interest.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Appointment letter, scope of review, and qualifications of the reviewer/certifier.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Review by stock exchanges and SEBI.
actionable_items.non_compliance_consequences: Potential regulatory action by SEBI, including penalties or restrictions on future issuances.

actionable_items.action_title: Maintain Decision-Making Process for Project Eligibility
actionable_items.action_description: Issuers of social bonds/sustainability bonds must maintain a decision-making process to determine the continuing eligibility of the project(s) and/or asset(s).
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: Effective from June 05, 2025, for all issuances of social bonds and sustainability bonds.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Establish and document a process for evaluating and selecting projects, ensuring they align with the stated objectives of the bonds.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Documented decision-making process, project evaluation criteria, and records of project selection.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Internal audits and review by the independent third-party reviewer/certifier.
actionable_items.non_compliance_consequences: Potential regulatory action by SEBI, including penalties or restrictions on future issuances.

actionable_items.action_description: Issuers must continuously monitor the social/sustainable impact of operations, avoid using funds for ineligible purposes, disclose instances of non-compliance, avoid misleading labels, quantify negative externalities, and avoid false claims of third-party certification.
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: Effective from June 05, 2025, for all issuances of social bonds and sustainability bonds.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Implement internal controls and monitoring mechanisms to prevent purpose-washing, including regular assessments of project impact and disclosure of any instances of non-compliance.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Internal control policies, monitoring reports, and disclosure documents.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Internal audits, review by the independent third-party reviewer/certifier, and scrutiny by investors and regulators.
actionable_items.non_compliance_consequences: Potential regulatory action by SEBI, including penalties, restrictions on future issuances, and early redemption of debt securities.

actionable_items.action_description: An Issuer who is eligible to list specified securities on SME exchange and intends to issue ESG debt securities shall have to comply with the post listing obligations as specified under ‘Continuous disclosure requirements’ specified in Annexure-A and Annexure-B, and paragraph 2 of Chapter IX (green Debt Securities) of SEBI NCS Master Circular bi-annually.

documents.summary: This circular provides limited relaxation from compliance with Regulation 58(1)(b) of the SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015, regarding the sending of hard copies of statements containing salient features of documents to holders of non-convertible securities who have not registered their email addresses. The relaxation is aligned with extensions granted by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) concerning the sending of physical copies of financial statements and is subject to certain conditions, including disclosure of web-links to the relevant statements.

key_clauses.clause_title: Relaxation from Regulation 58(1)(b) for entities complying with MCA Circular No. 09/2024
key_clauses.clause_content: Entities having listed non-convertible securities, who have complied with the conditions as specified in MCA general circular No.09/2024 dated September 19, 2024 and have not sent hard copy of statement containing the salient features of all the documents, as specified in Section 136 of Companies Act, 2013 and rules made thereunder, to those holders of non-convertible securities, who have not registered their email address, shall not be subject to any penal action for non-compliance with Regulation 58(1)(b) under the LODR Regulations for the period October 01, 2024 to June 05, 2025.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides relief from potential penalties for non-compliance with Regulation 58(1)(b) for entities that have adhered to the conditions outlined in MCA Circular No. 09/2024.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Avoidance of penal action for non-compliance with Regulation 58(1)(b) under LODR Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Relaxation from Regulation 58(1)(b) with Disclosure Requirement
key_clauses.clause_content: For the period June 06, 2025 to September 30, 2025, similar relaxation from the requirements of Regulation 58(1)(b) of the SEBI LODR Regulations is hereby provided for entities having listed non-convertible securities provided that advertisement in terms of Regulation 52(8) of the SEBI LODR Regulations shall disclose the web-link to the statement containing the salient features of all the documents, as specified in Section 136 of Companies Act, 2013 and rules made thereunder, so as to enable the holder of non-convertible securities to have access to the said the statement.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Extends the relaxation from sending hard copies, contingent upon disclosing a web-link to the statement containing salient features of documents in advertisements as per Regulation 52(8).
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Potential penalties for non-compliance with Regulation 58(1)(b) if the web-link disclosure requirement is not met.

documents.summary: This circular addresses the issue of accumulation of unsold invoked client securities in brokers' demat accounts and operational difficulties faced by brokers when clients sell pledged securities. It introduces a combined automated process for invocation and sale of pledged securities and provides a functionality for 'Pledge release for early pay in' to facilitate ease of doing business and safeguard investor interests. The circular amends Annexure A of circular dated February 25, 2020, and Para 41 of Master Circular for Stock Brokers dated August 09, 2024.

key_clauses.clause_title: Pledge Release for Early Pay In
key_clauses.clause_content: Depositories shall provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘Pledge release for early pay in’ to TM/CM wherein pledge will be released and early pay in block will be set up immediately in client demat account subject to pay in validation i.e. only to the extent of delivery obligation of that client as provided by CCs to depositories without the need for physical instruction or electronic instruction or DDPI/POA, in cases where client sells the securities, which are pledged in favor of TM/CM as Margin pledged securities (including pledged funded stock) / CUSPA pledge.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Facilitates easier and faster release of pledged securities when clients sell them, reducing operational burden on brokers and enabling smoother transactions.

key_clauses.clause_title: Invocation and Early Pay-In Block for Margin Pledged Securities
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of invocation of margin pledged securities (including pledged funded stock) of client by Trading member (TM), the invoked securities, other than mutual fund units that are not traded on the exchanges, shall be blocked for early pay-in in the client’s demat account with a trail being maintained in TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’ / ‘Client Securities under Margin Funding Account’. The pay in block in client’s demat account shall be subject to pay in validation i.e. only to the extent of delivery obligation of that client as provided by CCs to depositories.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that invoked securities are immediately blocked for early pay-in, preventing their misuse and facilitating their sale for realization of moneys.

key_clauses.clause_title: Invocation cum Redemption for Mutual Fund Units
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of invocation of Mutual fund (MF) units that are not traded on the exchange, depositories shall provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘invocation cum redemption’ wherein invoked MF units will come to the TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’, and go for auto redemption from the said account.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Streamlines the process of invoking and redeeming mutual fund units, making it more efficient.

key_clauses.clause_title: Handling Invoked Securities when Client Account is Frozen
key_clauses.clause_content: In scenarios, where client’s trading account is frozen or client trading codes are marked as ‘Not permitted to trade’ or equivalent at the stock exchanges subsequent to creation of pledge, the invoked securities will come to demat account of TM/CM and the same shall be sold by TM/CM under the proprietary code. In order to prevent the accumulation of client securities in the demat account of TM/CM, it must be ensured by TM/CM that pay-in of securities is done on the same day of invocation.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a mechanism for handling invoked securities when a client's account is frozen, ensuring that the securities are sold promptly to prevent accumulation in the broker's account.

actionable_items.action_title: Implementation of Pledge Release for Early Pay In Functionality
actionable_items.action_description: Depositories must implement a functionality for 'Pledge release for early pay in' that allows TM/CMs to release pledges and set up early pay-in blocks in client demat accounts with a single instruction, subject to pay-in validation.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: The functionality must ensure that the pledge is released and the early pay-in block is set up immediately, and that the pay-in validation is performed to ensure it is only to the extent of the client's delivery obligation.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not Specified

actionable_items.action_title: Implementation of Invocation cum Redemption Functionality for Mutual Funds
actionable_items.action_description: Depositories must implement a functionality for 'invocation cum redemption' that allows TM/CMs to invoke MF units and have them automatically redeemed from the TM/CM's ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: The functionality must ensure that the invoked MF units come to the TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’ and are automatically redeemed from that account.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not Specified

actionable_items.action_title: Implementation of Early Pay-In Block for Invoked Securities
actionable_items.action_description: TMs must ensure that invoked securities (other than non-traded mutual fund units) are blocked for early pay-in in the client's demat account, with a trail maintained in the TM/CM's ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’ / ‘Client Securities under Margin Funding Account’.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: The pay-in block must be subject to pay-in validation, ensuring it is only to the extent of the client's delivery obligation.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not Specified

actionable_items.action_title: Sale of Invoked Securities in Frozen Accounts
actionable_items.action_description: TM/CMs must sell invoked securities under their proprietary code and ensure pay-in of securities is done on the same day of invocation when a client's trading account is frozen or marked as 'Not permitted to trade'.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: TM/CMs must ensure that pay-in of securities is done on the same day of invocation to prevent accumulation of client securities in their demat account.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not Specified

actionable_items.action_description: Stock Exchanges, Clearing Corporations, and Depositories must bring the provisions of this circular to the notice of their members and disseminate the same on their websites.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Ensure all members are informed about the new provisions and that the information is readily available on their websites.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: SEBI will likely monitor websites for compliance.

actionable_items.action_description: Stock Exchanges, Clearing Corporations, and Depositories must make necessary amendments to their relevant Bye-laws, Rules, and Regulations for the implementation of the above direction.

documents.summary: This circular modifies the investor charter for Research Analysts to enhance financial consumer protection, financial inclusion, and financial literacy, considering recent developments like the ODR platform and SCORES 2.0. It directs BSE Limited (RAASB) to advise Research Analysts to bring the updated Investor Charter to the notice of their clients and continue disclosing complaint data on their websites and mobile applications.

key_clauses.clause_title: Modification of Investor Charter for Research Analysts
key_clauses.clause_content: The investor charter for Research Analysts is modified to enhance financial consumer protection, financial inclusion, and financial literacy, considering the introduction of the Online Dispute Resolution (ODR) platform and SCORES 2.0.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Research Analysts must adhere to the updated investor charter, impacting their interactions with clients and the information they provide.

key_clauses.clause_title: Disclosure of Investor Charter to Clients
key_clauses.clause_content: BSE Limited (RAASB) is directed to advise Research Analysts to bring the Investor Charter to the notice of their clients (existing as well as new clients) through disclosing the Investor Charter on their respective websites and mobile applications (if any), making them available at prominent places in the office, provide a copy of Investor Charter as a part of client on-boarding process, through e-mails/ letters etc.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Research Analysts must actively communicate the Investor Charter to their clients through various channels.

key_clauses.clause_content: All the Research Analysts shall continue to disclose on their respective websites and mobile applications (if any), the data on complaints received against them or against issues dealt by them and redressal thereof, latest by 7th of succeeding month, as per the format enclosed at Annexure ‘B’ to this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Research Analysts must maintain transparency by disclosing complaint data monthly.

key_clauses.clause_title: Rescinding of Previous Circular and Amendment of Master Circular
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/IMD-II CIS/P/CIR/2021/0685 dated December 13, 2021 stands rescinded and Clause 5 of Master Circular for Research Analysts dated May 21, 2024 stands amended as per this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: The previous circular is no longer in effect, and the Master Circular is amended to reflect the changes in this circular.

key_metrics.metric_description: Maximum time allowed for Research Analyst to redress a grievance.
key_metrics.threshold_significance: If grievance is not redressed within 21 days, the investor can file a complaint on SCORES or with RAASB.

key_metrics.metric_description: Deadline for Research Analysts to disclose complaint data on their websites/mobile applications.
key_metrics.threshold_significance: Failure to disclose complaint data by the 7th of the succeeding month constitutes non-compliance.

actionable_items.action_description: Research Analysts must implement the updated investor charter as per Annexure A.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Adherence to the updated Investor Charter.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not specified

actionable_items.action_description: Research Analysts must disclose the Investor Charter to their clients through their websites, mobile applications, prominent places in the office, as part of the client onboarding process, and through emails/letters.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Disclosure through multiple channels.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not specified
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not specified

actionable_items.action_description: Research Analysts must disclose data on complaints received and redressed on their websites and mobile applications as per the format in Annexure B.
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: Monthly, by the 7th of the succeeding month
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Accurate and timely disclosure of complaint data.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Complaint data in the format specified in Annexure B.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Not specified
